header.abstract: The Martha Jane Whiteside papers (dated 1948-2003; 6.28 cubic feet; 13 boxes, 2 flat boxes, 2 map folders) contains pamphlets, brochures, minutes, reports, notes, newsletters, clippings, and other publications which document Whiteside's civic engagement in Lexington, Fayette County, and Kentucky.

descriptive_summary.author: Kaylee McMunn
descriptive_summary.title: Martha Jane Whiteside papers
descriptive_summary.arrangement: Collection is arranged by subject into 5 series.

descriptive_summary.prefercite: 1997ms183: [identification of item], Martha Jane Whiteside papers, 1948-2003, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Martha Jane Whiteside (nee Livesay), born June 26, 1924 in San Antonio, Texas, was the daughter of United States Army pathologist Harvey R. Livesay. Due to her father's career in the army, she moved around the country with her family living in Hawaii; Washington, D.C.; and New York. After graduating from Barnard College of Columbia University in 1943, Whiteside worked as both an assistant and a librarian at the University of Kentucky. There, in 1952, she became a founding associate of Anvil Press alongside influential figures Carolyn Hammer (nee Reading), UK's rare book curator, and her husband, artist and typographer Victor Hammer. Anvil Press would eventually become King Library Press, UK's present-day university press. Mrs. Whiteside married University of Kentucky law professor Frederick W. Whiteside, Jr. (1913-2001).

Whiteside was involved in various Lexington-Fayette Urban County Government projects, from the preservation of Lexington neighborhoods to breaking ground for new housing and business developments. Specifically she served on the Lexington Fayette County Urban Government planning team to idenify grant projects. She kept abreast of district school policies, advocated for the environmental conservation of Kentucky's natural resources, and contributed to numerous community benefits. She served on the board of the Hunter Foundation for Healthcare. The non-profit organization was named for prominent African-American doctors, Dr. John E. Bush and his son Dr. Bush A. Hunter. The organization was later renamed Healthcare of the Bluegrass. Additionally, Whiteside served on the Kentucky Government Council. Whiteside was an active member of the Kentucky chapter of the League of Women Voters, advocating for women's equality and rights on a state and national level. Martha Jane Whiteside passed away in 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Martha Jane Whiteside papers (dated 1948-2003; 6.28 cubic feet; 13 boxes, 2 flat boxes, 2 map folders) contains pamphlets, brochures, minutes, reports, notes, newsletters, clippings, and other publications which document Whiteside's civic engagement in Lexington, Fayette County, and Kentucky. The collection is arranged by subject into five series.

The Civic Affairs series comprises primarily brochures, pamphlets, reports, and assorted publications related to Whiteside's involvement with historical preservation and tourism in Kentucky, local organizations and industry, national government and news, and performance arts and museums. The bulk of the series comprises brochures, newsletters, clippings, directories, reports and other publications related to the Kentucky chapter of the League of Women Voters, of which Whiteside was an active member.

The Hunter Foundation series comprises reports, meeting minutes and agendas, clippings, and other publications from the organization. Also included is a timeline map for the organization's activities, dated 1972-1973.

The Kentucky Government Council series comprises reports, brochures, correspondence, newsletters, legislative calendars, and other publications related to the Council's environmental policies, health and human services, the Kentucky General Assembly, state governance and personnel, and revenue and finance. The council, a statewide committee of thirty community leaders, was organized in 1961 to provide non-partisan leadership in research, citizen education, and action.

The Lexington-Fayette Urban County Government (LFUCG) series comprises reports, brochures, calendars and schedules, meeting minutes, notes, and other publications related to administration and governance of the LFUCG, community services, the Community Development Block Grant projects, the Comprehensive Planning Commission, and land development and zoning policies in Lexington and Fayette County. The series reflects Whitesides involvement and work with the LFUCG.
The Personal series comprises correspondence, invitations, programs, and other publications related to Whiteside's personal interests and associations.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.
